chapter.title: Using the OBS Web UI
chapter.para: This chapter explains and shows how you could use OBS Web UI. We will show and use OBS Web UI based on . You need to make an account first to follow this chapter contents.

sect1.title: Homepage and Login
sect1.para: Open a browser and navigate to
To proceed, you'll need to log in and authenticate with your username and your password. Click on Login and enter the data in the upper right corner.
After successful authentication, you'll end up on the start page again - with new options visible. We'll go through most of them in detail, but first lets create your home: in the next step.

sect1.title: Home Project
sect1.para: Every user has a home project (home:[userid]) where they have write access by default. This is a personal workspace where you can experiment and play. Click on the link "Home Project" at the upper right to get to your home project.

sect2.title: The Project Page
sect2.para: Your home project will be empty for now, but you can add packages containing sources/build recipes and projects which are containers for the build targets. As you can see, you're the default maintainer which grants you full write access to this project. You're also the bug owner of your project.

sect2.title: Changing a project's title and description
sect2.para: On every project page you will find a "Edit description" link. This link will lead you to a place were you can review and change your project's title and description. Click on the "Update project" button to save.

sect2.title: Creating Subprojects to a Project
sect2.para: Subprojects are projects that are part of another projects namespace. Subprojects are an easy way to organize multiple projects. On the "Subprojects" tab you can find a list subprojects that belong to a project. To create a new subproject click on the "New subproject" link, fill in the form and press the "Create project" button.

note.para: Maintainers of upper projects can always modify the subprojects. Apart from that all projects are separated and have no influence on each other.

sect1.title: My Projects, Server Status
sect1.para: For now, let's leave your home for a bit and explore the build service. Click on "My Projects" on the left at the bottom. This opens a page listing your watched projects and your involvements in projects or packages.

Now, let's visit the main monitor page by clicking on "Status Monitor". You see here the status of the services, some graphs and graphics are showing the currently running and completed jobs and the overall load.

sect1.title: Create a link to a package in your home:
sect1.para: We'll show you how you can log in and use the web interface hosted at build.opensuse.org. This includes login, adding a link to a package in your personal workspace (home:) and how to build that package by adding a repository. First, let's enter "My Projects" by clicking on the link at the bottom left.

Now let's create a link to a package and add a repository to build against. A link is basically a pointer to sources of an already existing package. By "repository" we mean container of built binary packages like Debian_8 or openSUSE_13.2. Let's follow these steps:

sect1.title: Repository Output: Built Packages
sect1.para: To find the RPMs you built, go to your home project page and click Repositories. From there click on the blue repository name. For example, openSUSE_Factory:

note.para: Published repositories are marked with the OBS truck

sect1.para: Now click Go to download repository. Note that publishing the repository might take a while. Before the binary repository is published, you will receive a 404 error. When the binaries are available, you will see something like this:
Your rpms can be found in the subdirectories, and the .repo file is suitable for use with zypper, yum or other repository-friendly package management tools.

sect1.title: Managing Repositories
sect1.para: This section will show how you can manage your project's repositories.

sect2.title: Adding a repository
sect2.para: To add a repository to your project, click on "Add Repositories" on the project's repository tab. This will direct you to a list of possible distributions you can build packages for, see .

figure.title: Adding a Repository to a Project

note.para: If you could not find a repository that fits your needs, you might want to switch to the expert mode. Click on the "Expert mode" link right to the button. This page allows you to search and select a repository of any project available in OBS and add it to your projects repository list.

sect2.para: This will take you back to your home: project. The build repository might be disabled: if so, click on the cogwheel to enable it. Congratulations, it is configured. On a heavily loaded server, it can sometimes take a few minutes for your changes to become effective, but your linked package will automatically begin building.

sect2.title: Add Download on Demand repositories to a project
sect2.para: When you have administrator rights you will be able to add Download on Demand repositories to your project. To do so, click on the "Add DoD repository" link and enter your DoD repository data into the form.

figure.title: Adding a Download on Demand Repository

sect2.para: The minimal set of fields you have to enter are architecture, repository type and the URL that provides the binary packages. Detailed information about the data you can enter here you can find at the DoD concept section. Press "Save" to create the repository.
When the repository got added you are able to edit, delete or add additional DoD repository sources.

sect2.title: Adding DoD Repository Sources to a Repository

figure.title: Adding Download on Demand repository sources

sect2.para: Open the DoD repository sources form by clicking the "Add" link. Here you can enter your additional DoD repository source. Click the "Add Download on Demand" button.

figure.title: Form for Adding DoD Repository Sources

sect2.title: Editing DoD Repository Sources
sect2.para: To edit DoD repository sources after they got added click on the "Edit" link that you find right to each DoD repository source.

figure.title: Form for editing DoD repository sources

sect2.title: Editing DoD Repository Sources
sect2.para: To delete a repository or repository source, click on the "Delete" link and accept the confirmation dialog.
